hedline.hl1: Major Indexes Post Gains, Nudged Higher by Chip Shares

abstract.p: Dow Jones industrial average rises 14.85 points, or 0.1 percent, to 10,699.97; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 10.18 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,474.47; Nasdaq composite index gains 48 points, or 1.2 percent, to 4,029.57; graph; chart (M)

block.p: The main stock market gauges rose for the first time in three sessions yesterday, led by solid gains in big semiconductor companies like Intel and Applied Materials.
But the rise in prices was far from uniform. On the New York Stock Exchange, the ratio of stocks that rose to those that lost value was about even.
The main stock market gauges rose for the first time in three sessions yesterday, led by solid gains in big semiconductor companies like Intel and Applied Materials.
But the rise in prices was far from uniform. On the New York Stock Exchange, the ratio of stocks that rose to those that lost value was about even.

''It was a pretty lackluster session, but at least we finished in the green,'' said Bryan Piskorowski, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. ''The one positive was a rebound in semiconductor stocks.''
The Dow Jones industrial average rose a meager 14.85 points, or 0.1 percent, to 10,699.97, led by Intel, Wal-Mart and Procter & Gamble.
Gains in Cisco Systems and Nortel Networks helped to lift the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by 10.18 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,474.47.
The Nasdaq composite index did better, gaining 48 points, or 1.2 percent, to 4,029.57.
Over the previous two sessions, the Nasdaq had fallen 4.9 percent on concern that profit growth would slow in the third and fourth quarters.

Chip-related stocks rallied after the Semiconductor Equipment Association of Japan said sales soared 126 percent in May. That report followed stronger-than-expected earnings from Texas Instruments, which posted its results after the market closed on Monday and painted a bright outlook for the rest of the year.
Among chip stocks, Intel gained 2 7/8, to 140 7/8. Micron Technology rose 1 7/8, to 86 3/4. And Applied Materials rose 4, to 84 1/2.
Aside from the news on semiconductor sales, there was not much to impress traders or investors.

Analysts said the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, offered few insights during semiannual testimony before the House Banking Committee on whether policy makers will raise short-term interest rates at their Aug. 22 meeting.

The lack of guidance places even greater importance on data that will be released over the next few weeks, including reports on second-quarter gross domestic product and the employment cost index, a key inflation measure. The employment cost index is scheduled to be released tomorrow. And the first estimate of second-quarter economic growth is expected on Friday.
''Basically, Mr. Greenspan is saying they don't know what they are going to do on Aug. 22,'' said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald.
Mr. Piskorowski added, ''Greenspan made it plain they are waiting to see what the data are showing before they will make a decision.''
Drug shares were generally weak yesterday after a report from Pfizer showed slower-than-expected revenue growth.

Pfizer fell 3 7/8, to 43 11/16. Bristol-Myers Squibb lost 1 9/64, to 48 13/16. Schering-Plough dropped 1 61/64, to 43 5/16. And Eli Lilly eked out a gain of 3/64 after slipping earlier, and ended at 10 13/16.

Amazon.com was another loser. Shares of the Internet retailer fell 1 1/8, to 37 5/8, after the company said Joseph Galli, its president and chief operating officer, was leaving to become chief executive of VerticalNet Inc. Mr. Galli had held those positions for only a year.

Reuters Group, the financial information provider, rose 3 3/4, to 119 1/4, after it reported that first-half earnings soared 75 percent, in large part because of higher revenue from Instinet, its online trading network.
But MedQuist tumbled 12 3/8, or 40 percent, to 18 13/16, after the medical records transcriber reported operating profits that were weaker than expected.
Treasury Prices Mixed
(By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices were mixed yesterday on speculation that the Federal Reserve was less likely to raise interest rates at its Aug. 22 meeting.

The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, in comments to the House Banking Committee, said a decision on interest rate policy would depend on the economic data coming in the next few weeks.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 3/32, to 106 8/32. The bond's yield remained at 5.81 percent.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note was unchanged at 103 8/32; its yield was 6.03 percent.
